summary.para: Enumeration representing the frequency an object wishes to have it's Update() method called (With a special case to have the object removed from the update list).

member.name: F:Xen.UpdateFrequency.OncePerFrame
member.summary: Call update once per frame

summary.para: Call update once per frame asynchronously with other instances
Note: Update implementations need to be thread safe when using asynchronous updates. Async adds overhead which can make simple Update methods slower!

remarks.para: Asynchronous updates have an overhead for setup of the asynchronous update process.
If there are fewer items to be updated than threads, then the update processes will not be run asynchronously.

member.name: T:Xen.IDraw
member.summary: Interface to an object that can be drawn. All drawable objects also are

remarks.para: Some objects, such as draw targets need to have Draw called explicitly, while some objects may have called from another object.

A call to should not assume the object knows it's full render state. Simple geometry classes, for example, may only draw themselves. In such a case, the 'owner' IDraw object should make sure the correct render states, shaders, etc are setup first.

member.name: T:Xen.IContentOwner
member.summary: Interface to an object that wishes to load content through an XNA , or handle implementation specific content load/unload logic, for use with the class (such as the instance)

remarks.para: This interface is intended as a lightweight replacement for the content loading methods found in

All XNA content should be loaded within these methods, with the exception of Textures returned by and .
These textures become invalid after a call to , they are guarenteed to be valid again during the subsequent call.
When registered with a object, a weak reference of the instance will be stored. This will prevent the object from being kept alive in an unexpected way

member.name: M:Xen.DrawState.DrawDynamicIndexedVertices``1(``0[],System.Int32[],Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)

summary.para: Draw dynamic vertices as primitives with extended parametres, using an index buffer (indices)
NOTE: When using this method, the vertex and index data will be copied every frame.
This method is best for volatile vertex data that is changing every frame.
Use a dynamic Vertices object for dynamic data that changes less frequently, or requires use with a VerticesGroup objcet.

member.param: source vertex data to use for drawing vertices
indices to use when drawing
Primitive type to use when drawing the buffer
The number of primitives to draw
The start index in the index buffer (defaults to the first index - 0)
Starting offset into the vertex buffer (defaults to the first vertex - 0)
The maximum index used by the index buffer. This determines how many vertices will be copied (zero will copy all vertices)

When true, this Projections frustum cull planes will not be updated.
This can be used to 'pause' frustum culling, while still allowing the camera to move. This allows visual debugging of off screen culling.

member.name: P:Xen.Camera.Projection.Aspect
member.summary: Gets/Sets the aspect ratio of the projection. (Specify 'null' to have the aspect ratio computed by the width and height of the draw target)

remarks.para: An aspect ratio of 1 is a square projection
Aspect ratios are most commonly set to the Width/Height of the current render target, this will be automatically calculated if is set to null.
Aspect ratio has no effect on an orthographic projection

member.name: P:Xen.Camera.Projection.FarClip
member.summary: Gets/Sets the far clipping plane distance of the projection (See remarks for more details)

remarks.para: The far clipping plane represents how far geometry will be visible before it goes outside of the z buffers range

member.name: P:Xen.Camera.Projection.NearClip
member.summary: Gets/Sets the near clipping plane distance of the projection

remarks.para: The near clip plane distance determines how close geometry can get to the camera before it goes outside of the range of the z buffer, and gets clipped
Note, the z-buffer stores depth as non-linear values. A value close to the near clip plane will be closer to 0, and will be stored with greater accuracy
Further values will have larger z values, and have lower precision.
Consider:
An apprximate measure of the accurate range of the depth buffer is FarClip / NearClip. The smaller the value, the more accurate.
Therefore, to double z-buffer accuracy, you can either halve the FarClip or double the NearClip. Consider the implications of both if the NearClip is 0.01 and the FarClip is 10,000.
In short, keep the NearClip value as large as you can. (default value is 1)

member.name: T:Xen.Graphics.IIndices
member.summary: Interface to an index buffer. Stores an list of indexes to vertices.

remarks.para: An example index buffer, to draw a Square from four vertices using a (A list of triangles) the vertices would be the four corners, while the indices would be:

In this case (), each set of 3 numbers index vertices to make a triangle. (0,1,2) is the first triangle, between the first, second and third vertex. While (0,2,3) is the second triangle, between the first, third and fourth (last) vertices. This creates a Square (or Quad).

member.name: F:Xen.Graphics.ResourceUsage.Dynamic
member.summary: Buffer will be allocated in a way optimised for content that changes frequently

member.name: F:Xen.Graphics.ResourceUsage.DynamicSequential
member.summary: [Use with caution] Buffer is allocated as . All data writes are assumed to be non-overlapping and performed in order starting from zero. (See remarks for details)

remarks.para: This flag is the equivalent of using for any data changes starting at zero, and for the rest.
Hence it is a requirement that data copies be done in-order, and always starting from zero for their use order.

The way to use this flag is with a large buffer that gets small amounts of data written over a number of frames (with each small block of data not overwriting previous, and writes being performed in order starting from zero).

NOTE: Misuse of this flag can cause unexpected behaviour. What you are seeing on screen can be upto 5 frames behind what the CPU is processing. The driver will assume buffer writes not starting at zero are copying to memory that the application is no longer using. Hence misuse of this flag makes it possible to have the CPU write data to the GPU that will then get used to draw a previous frame. If such a case occurs without using this flag, the CPU will wait for the GPU to catch up, so the copy does not overwrite data that may be in use (this can cause a significant pipeline stall)
IMPORTANT: Also note, due to the usage cases for DynamicSequential, when the buffer is created it's data will not be automatically filled. A call to SetDirtyRange() will be required first.

member.name: T:Xen.Graphics.StateFlag
member.summary: Flags to represent aspects of the graphics render state that may be tracked by the application

remarks.para: This flag is used to specify what render states has become 'dirty'
Internally the application keeps track of what it thinks the render state is, to make changing state more efficient.
By specifying that a render state group is dirty, the application ignores what it thinks the state is, and assumes it is entirely different.
This forces the application to reapply all states the next time something is drawn.

member.name: T:Xen.Graphics.AlphaBlendState
member.summary: Packed representation of common Alpha Blending states. 4 bytes

remarks.para: When a pixel is drawn, it usually overwrites the existing pixel.

For example, if you draw a quad in the centre of the screen, drawing that quad draws over the existing pixels on screen. Usually before drawing the quad, you would clear the screen first. If the screen is cleared to black, and the quad is white, the existing black colour values are overwritten with white colour values.
The existing pixels are known as the 'destination' pixels, and the pixels being written are known as 'source' pixels.
In the example, the desination pixels are black colour values, while the source pixels are white colour values.
When alpha blending is enabled, the value that is written is the result of an equation.

A common alpha blending operation is 'additive' blending, where the source and destination colours are added together (this is commonly used in particle effects such as light flares and fire, as it 'adds' light, and brightens the on screen image (the destination pixels)) :
In such a case, the pixels already on screen (destination) will mostly stay visible, with the pixels being drawn (source) added to them
To set additive blending, the following states should be set:
What does this mean? Alpha blending can be more complex than simple additive blending. To understand, you need to know the complete blending equation.
The actual blending equation is:
As can be seen, it's more complex. With the settings used above above, the equation becomes:
The blend operations and modes control only the mathematical operations used in the equation.

This simple blending mode works well in a lot of cases, but you can quickly add too much colour. Most render targets (and the screen) are low precision, and cannot store r/g/b/a values greater than 1.0, so addtive blending can quickly lead to 'blown out' effects that clamp to full white (RGB = 1,1,1)

An example of a more complex blending mode is Alpha Blending. Not to be confused by the name, 'Alpha Blending' as a blend state and 'Alpha Blending' as a device render state are different things. For clarity, I'll call it 'SourceAlpha blending'

With SourceAlpha blending, the source pixels store an alpha value that represents how transparent they are. Eg, the texture for leaves on a tree will store an alpha value of 1.0 on the leaf pixels, and a value of 0.0 around them in the 'transparent' pixels.
To achieve SourceAlpha blending, the blend equation needs to perform a linear interpolation (fade) from the destination (background) to the source (tree leaves).
A simple linear interpolation is...
Or in blend states:
Converted to a AlphaBlendState object, this becomes:
Note that 'InverseSourceAlpha' really means 'OneMinusSourceAlpha'. This is important if you use high precision render targets that can store values above 1.0!
Also, For advanced use, can be set to true, doing so allows defining a separate equation just for the alpha channel, like so:
remarks.code: destination.rgb = (destination.rgb * DestinationBlend) BlendOperation (source.rgb * SourceBlend); destination.a = (destination.a * DestinationBlendAlpha) BlendOperationAlpha (source.a * SourceBlendAlpha);
remarks.para: Note: If the blend mode modifies the destination ( is anything other than ), then drawing pixels in different orders will produce different results. This is especially true if depth writing is still enabled, as drawing the pixel does not completely overwrite the previous colour. For example, if multiple trees are drawn, potentially one on top of the other, then it is best to draw the trees in order from back to front.

member.name: P:Xen.Graphics.DepthState.DepthTestEnabled
member.summary: Gets/Sets if depth testing is enabled

remarks.para: If depth testing is disabled, then pixels will always be drawn, even if they are behind another object on screen.

member.name: P:Xen.Graphics.DepthState.DepthWriteEnabled
member.summary: Gets/Sets if depth writing is enabled

remarks.para: If depth writing is disabled, pixels that are drawn will still go through normal depth testing, however they will not write a new depth value into the depth buffer. This is most useful for transparent effects, and any effect that does not have a physical representation (eg, a light cone, particle effects, etc).

Usually, 'solid' objects with depth writing enabled will be drawn first. Such as the world, characters, models, etc. Then non-solid and effect geometry is drawn without depth writing. If this order is reversed, the solid geometry can overwrite the effects.

member.name: P:Xen.Graphics.DepthState.DepthTestFunction
member.summary: Changes the comparsion function used when depth testing. WARNING: On some video cards, changing this value can disable hierarchical z-buffer optimizations for the rest of the frame

remarks.para: Changing the depth test function from Less to Greater midframe is not recommended.
Changing between and is usually OK.
On newer video cards, keeping the depth test function consistent throughout the frame will still maintain peek effciency, however some older cards are only full speed when using or
Setting to false is the preferred to using .

member.name: T:Xen.Graphics.StencilState
member.summary: Packed representation of Stencil Testing state. 8 bytes

remarks.para: On most systems, the depth buffer is either 32 or 16 bits in size. However, with a 32bit size depth buffer, the accuracy is usually only 24bits. (True 32bit depth buffers are not supported on any DX9 video cards)
When the depth is 24bits, the remaining 8bits can be used as the stencil buffer (see ).
In this case the stencil buffer is an 8bit integer format, (similar to a single colour in 32bit RGBA). Values range from 0 to 255.
The difference with a stencil buffer is that operations performed on it are based almost entirely on bitmasks, increments/decrements and swapping values. It acts in a similar way to a .net .
The name 'stencil testing' is somewhat misleading as it involves two operations, stencil reading and stencil writing.
When stencil testing is enabled, both of these are enabled, however the default comparisons and write maskes/options all have no effect.
For example, to 'mask' an area on screen (eg, to draw into a circle, and only a circle) then then stencil testing can be used in two passes:
Assuming the stencil buffer is cleared to zero, the circle can be drawn first.

With stencil testing enabled, the circile is drawn. The stencil reference value () is set to 1. The is set to , which means the value in the stencil buffer (when the pixel is drawn) will be replaced with the reference value (which is 1). Setting to None may be desired to make the circle not visible.

Next, the scene inside the circle is drawn. With stencil testing enabled, the reference is set to 1 again and the is set to . This way, the stencil function will only pass when the stencil value in the stencil buffer is equal to the reference value of 1. This way nothing outside the circle is drawn.
Note that the ciricle will still be drawn into the stencil buffer at this stage.
Stencil testing has more complex features. The most significant, is that the stencil value can be modified in different ways for three cases.
These cases are: When the stencil function passes, the stencil function passes but Z-testing fails and finally when the stencil function fails.
Finally, stencil testing can be configured independantly for backfacing triangles (by setting to true). (Note that must also be set to None for this to take effect).
Stencil testing can be used for some very complex effects, such as stencil shadows.
An example is determining how many pixels are within a closed convex volume (such as a sphere or cube) that does not intersect the near or far clip plane. Assuming a stencil buffer cleared to zero:

In such a case, drawing the volume (with colour writes and depth writes disabled) and setting the stencil pass operation to and the stencil backface z-fail stencil operation to will leave the stencil buffer unchanged for all pixels that are within the volume.
Drawing the volume again, with stencil function set to Equal to a reference value of 0, only those existing pixels within the volume will be drawn.

member.name: T:Xen.Graphics.Vertices`1
member.summary: Generic vertex buffer, automatically copies data and sets up a object.

remarks.para: Vertices objects are created by passing in the vertex data to the constructor.
There are two constructors, one for IEnumerable data and a params T[] constructor, for for directly passing in values.
The class knows about common types like the generic List class.
Once created, the vertices object can be used. No further setup is required.

The vertices class will examine the array data type and construct a vertex declaration automatically. (Provided the structure members are public, are hardware supported types and are logically named). If this automatic generation fails, then the attribute can be used to exactly specify structure layout.
See for more details.

example.para: Using the existing XNA vertex structures to create four vertices:
example.code: IVertices verts = new Vertices<VertexPositionColor>( new VertexPositionColor(new Vector3(0,0,0), Color.Red), new VertexPositionColor(new Vector3(0,1,0), Color.Green), new VertexPositionColor(new Vector3(1,1,0), Color.Green), new VertexPositionColor(new Vector3(1,0,0), Color.Red));

remarks.para: To create a dynamic vertex buffer, set the of the buffer to .Dynamic before it's used

example.code: verts = new new Vertices<VertexPositionColor>(items); verts.ResourceUsage = ResourceUsage.Dynamic;

remarks.para: When a buffer is allocated dynamically, you can tell the buffer it's source data has changed by calling or . (The source data is the collection passed into the constructor). Internally the vertices object only keeps a weak reference to the source data.

member.name: T:Xen.Graphics.StreamFrequency
member.summary: Sets parametres for hardware instancing when drawing with a VerticesGroup object (Supported on windows with vertex shader 3 or greater, emulated on Xbox360 when using )

remarks.para: Hardware instancing is not supported on the xbox 360, only PCs with vertex shader model 3.0 are supported.
However, when using , support is emulated on the Xbox by repeating index data.
Hardware instancing uses two or more vertex buffers, with each buffer being repeated.

Common usage, would be to have the first buffer store the model geometry, repeated X number of times. With the second buffer storing per-instance data, such as the world matrix. Instance data is repeated for each vertex. A 5 vertex mesh drawn 3 times will repeat the instance (world matrix) data AAAAABBBBBCCCCC, where the vertices are repeated ABCDEABCDEABCDE.
The DrawBatch methods in are an easy way to automatically setup the instance data buffer in an optimal way.
Supporting instancing in a shader is fairly simple:
Instead of using the WORLDVIEWPROJECTION matrix to transform your vertices, use the VIEWPROJECTION matrix multipled by the world matrix from instance data:
Non instancing example:
Instancing example:
This can also be done with a simple structure:
It is highly recommended to implement shader-instancing for rendring smaller batches of small objects, or for supporting instancing on older hardware and the xbox
Shader instancing is a technique where the instance matrices are stored as shader constants, and the vertex/index data is duplicated to draw multiple instances.
The disadvantage is the extra memory overhead is considerable for large meshes. Each vertex must also store an index to the instance matrix to use.
For vertex-shader 2.0, there is uaully room for an array of 50-60 matrices

member.name: T:Xen.Graphics.VerticesGroup
member.summary: Stores a group of instances, sharing their unique elements in a single

remarks.para: This class can be used to draw vertices from multiple vertex buffers, sharing the first instance of each element type.
For example, the first vertex buffer may specify positions, while the second may specify normals. Using a is a way to share this data, without creating a new resource.

member.name: T:Xen.UpdateManager
member.summary: UpdateManager stores a list of object instances and manages calling

remarks.para: An update manager may be added to another update manager (as it implements IUpdate), this can make separating application logic easier.

member.name: M:Xen.UpdateManager.#ctor
member.summary: Construct the update manager

member.name: M:Xen.UpdateManager.Add(Xen.IUpdate)
member.summary: Add an item to the update manager in direct order (See remarks for more information)
member.remarks: See remarks for more information

member.name: M:Xen.UpdateManager.Add(Xen.IUpdate,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Add an item to the update manager either sequential order or directly. See remarks for details
member.param: See remarks for details

remarks.para: When an item is added to an UpdateManager, it will be put in a temporary list. When main updating completes items in this list will have their method called. This will determine their desired so they can be inserted into the main update list.
Therefore if any items are created before or during the update manager's update loop, those items will also have called in that frame (once all other updating has completed).
The next time they have Update called, they will be in the main list of items.

Because many items are often inserted into the update manager at once, and because items may not require they have Update called every update frame (usually for performance reasons), it is possible that the items updating at (for example) 5 times per second will mostly be at the same timestep, and not evenly distributed.

By specifying as true, the items will be inserted into the manager such that they have Update called on differet frames. If 12 items are added at 5hz, then the first item will Update on the first frame, the second on the second frame, and so on. Because there are 12 items, and 60 frames, there should be no frame where two or more items have Update called. This should help to ballance CPU load.

However, this system only places items in order by sequency, and does not do more intelligent placement (eg, inserting in the shortest list). The second time the item has Update() called the will be incorrect.
SeqentialDistribution only affects adding the item, it does not change the logic for when an item changes it's updat frequency

member.name: M:Xen.UpdateManager.Remove(Xen.IUpdate)
member.summary: Remove an item from the update manager. Returning from an item's implementation will also remove the item.
member.returns: returns true if the item was removed

member.name: M:Xen.UpdateManager.RemoveAll
member.summary: Remove all items from the update manager

member.name: P:Xen.UpdateManager.Enabled
member.summary: Gets/Sets if this update manager is enabled. When disabled, child items will not be updated.

remarks.para: As update managers can be nested within eachother, Disabling an entire update manager can be an effective way to disable large portions of a games logic structure.

summary.para: If true, the update manager will pause all updating when is false
(Items updating at will still update as normal)
Update Speed scale factor, 1.0 represents full update speed, 0.5 represents halved update speed, etc.
